title: Freedmen's Bureau Records: George T. Cook to R. S. Lacey, October 31, 1866
summary: Cook's detailed monthly report includes his commentary on the problems of labor and employment, low wages, the struggles to provide for children in freedmen's families, poll taxes, and the level of political engagement in Augusta County. He concludes his letter by stating: "The prejudice of the white man against allowing any rivalry by the black man must be conquered before the latter can become in the full sense of the word, free."
keywords: Economy, Employment/Labor, Family, Politics/Political Attitudes, Race Relations, Slavery, Local Government, American Civil War
